text: Are there any marketers here who’d be open to sharing their struggle with shiny object syndrome (chasing every other idea that comes to them without thinking it through)? This is for an article that I’m doing on the topic. If you’re interested, please message me here on Slack and I’ll send a few questions your way to learn how you’ve dealt with SOS and how you suggest others can too. No call needed. Thank you!

text: :raising_hand:

Hello there, question for everyone here:

In your opinion, which SaaS companies do you find the most-engaging content?

I'm working on a new piece, "SaaS content writing," and want some examples of SaaS companies with the best content.

If you want a backlink and brand feature in my piece, just add a comment on what you love about the SaaS blog you mention.

Thank you.

elements.text:

In your opinion, which SaaS companies do you find the most-engaging content?

If you want a backlink and brand feature in my piece, just add a comment on what you love about the SaaS blog you mention.

Thank you.

:one:  Directive (where I work) has a great blog (<https://directiveconsulting.com/blog/>) where we share what we've learned launching our own Saas product called Pulse (<https://directiveconsulting.com/pulse/>).

text: :three:  Restaurant365 has a blog that is doing some REALLY great work to support their struggling users right now: <https://www.restaurant365.com/resources/blog/> I live that they're meeting their customers where they're at and focusing more on providing value for them than closing new deals and converting visitors.

attachments.title: Blog | Restaurant365
attachments.text: As a restaurant owner or operator, you should always be looking for ways to save time and money. Learn more about restaurant automation and explore our blog.

text: Probably a boring answer, but Intercom. They’ve definitely found a really good formula because it’s one of the few blogs I subscribe to that has consistently good writing + insights, and I don’t even use their product.

text: :wave:

Hey folks, is there anyone here that's a freelancer (or have a recommendation) and experienced in writing about shipping and fulfillment? Think topics like 3PL, shipping providers/rates, packaging etc.

elements.text: Hey folks, is there anyone here that's a freelancer (or have a recommendation) and experienced in writing about shipping and fulfillment? Think topics like 3PL, shipping providers/rates, packaging etc.

text:
Crossbeam has made business partnerships actually interesting and worth reading. They’ve published really strong immersive articles like this <https://blog.crossbeam.com/software-saas-era-ecosystems>, but an oft-overlooked part is their formatting and structure. Whether it’s the “How to Partner With Me” series (<https://blog.crossbeam.com/how-to-partner-with-me-typeforms-francois-grenier>), the “Now What?” series (<https://blog.crossbeam.com/youre-the-first-partner-manager-at-your-company.-now-what>), their fill in the blank series (<https://blog.crossbeam.com/hubspot-andrew-lindsay>), etc., it’s inspiring. <@UJE5LQ2JC> runs that.

WeTransfer’s WePresent is really good too (<https://wepresent.wetransfer.com/>). It’s unique because it’s purely brand-driven, and they get millions of visitors monthly clicking through from the WeTransfer page. Probably one of the most creative publications online. Check out the video they produced with Bjork (<https://wepresent.wetransfer.com/story/wetransfer-presents-arisen-my-senses-a-video-by-bjork-and-jesse-kanda/>). For writing, check out this piece: <https://wepresent.wetransfer.com/story/music-in-eritrea-allyn-gaestel/>

Autodesk’s Redshift, Adobe’s 99U, Wealthsimple Diaries, Stripe’s Increment (and Atlas and Indiehackers) — all of those are worth looking into as well :slightly_smiling_face:

text: What’s the most useful career development book you’ve read? (Looking to add to the library in the next week or two!)

elements.text: What’s the most useful career development book you’ve read? (Looking to add to the library in the next week or two!)

text:
I read ~2 books a week — a mix of business-y/marketing stuff and academic stuff. Best book I've ever read is Don't Shoot the Dog, by Karen Pryor

<https://www.amazon.com/Dont-Shoot-Dog-Teaching-Training/dp/0553380397>

elements.text: I read ~2 books a week — a mix of business-y/marketing stuff and academic stuff. Best book I've ever read is Don't Shoot the Dog, by Karen Pryor

text:
Not specifically a career development work, but a book that has had a ridiculously large impact on my career -- Switch: How to Change Things When Change is Hard.

I still think about the lessons in this book all the time. Professional work means you're constantly persuading people, getting them to work together, selling them on an idea, asking them to do hard/annoying, things that they may not want to immediately do.

One of my favorite maxims in this book: "What looks like a people problem is usually a situation problem"

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

elements.text:

text:
I like Trello’s blog: <https://blog.trello.com/|https://blog.trello.com/>

It has a distinct brand voice—one that’s engaging for sure as well as backs claims with science. I also like it how they cover actionable guides that tell readers how to boost their productivity, work remote, and so. Plus, they’ve case studies for getting a better understanding of how their customers are using and how others can use their service to manage different projects.

elements.text: I like Trello’s blog:

text: I love and consistently look forward to reading Zendesk’s Relate blog. It’s a thought leadership focused publication and has a combo of interviews, first person experiences, research based articles and opinion pieces. Overall it shows the human side of customer experience (their product being support software).
